Award.AwardTitle: Pan American Advanced Studies Institute on Topics in Percolative and Disordered Systems; Argentina and Chile; January 1-15, 2012
Award.AbstractNarration:
PASI: Topics in Percolative and Disordered Systems

This Pan-American Advanced Studies Institutes (PASI) award, jointly supported by the NSF and the Department of Energy (DOE), will take place from January 1 to 15, 2012; the first week at the Pontificia Universidad Cat√≥lica (PUC) de Chile, in Santiago, Chile, and the second week at the Universidad de Buenos Aires in Buenos Aires, Argentina. Organized by Dr. Charles M. Newman of New York University together with Dr. Vladas Sidoravicius of IMPA, Brazil and CWI, the Netherlands, this PASI will address important and long-standing problems at the interface of mathematics and statistical physics.

The PASI is scheduled around 12 mini-courses in various research areas of percolation and disordered systems, some of them providing training in state-of-the-art techniques, and others addressing important open problems in probability and statistical physics. The study of percolation itself provides a convenient ground to develop techniques and increased understanding of phenomena like growth and pattern formation in complex interacting systems. Such techniques can be applied in a variety of fields, including hydrology, materials science, neural science, theoretical computer science, hydrology and petroleum engineering.

Lectures and activities for this PASI will be led by an outstanding group of researchers. Participants will include 30 graduate students, post-docs, and junior faculty from the hemisphere, half of which will be from the United States. The PASI will likely also attract additional prominent researchers from Latin America. The format will allow young researchers to enter challenging subjects with the guidance of active researchers in the community. This award will also greatly broaden the international workshop program of Dr. Newman's NSF PIRE project by providing a cutting-edge, international experience to many more U.S. and Latin American students, postdocs, and junior faculty members. Results from the PASI will be disseminated through a published version of the mini-courses and appropriate web sites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Pan American Advanced Studies Institute took place from January 2 to 15, 2012 with the first week in Santiago, Chile  and the second week in Buenos Aires, Argentina. The general area of the Institute was in Probability Theory and Statistical Physics. More specifically it concerned percolative and disordered systems in which randomness at the microscopic level leads to observable effects on transport and other properties at the macroscopic level.  Twenty-four PhD students and postdoctoral scientists (thirteen US and eleven non-US) attended  eight minicourses as well as additional research level seminars over the two week period of the Institute.  The cutting edge research presented in these courses and seminars will play a major role in the development of the student/participants during their training and scientific careers. The Pan-American nature of the Institute will also help in developing an international perspective for the US participants. A conference proceedings volume is to be published by Springer Publishing with whom a contract has been signed. This volume will make the content of many of the minicourses and seminars available to students, postdoctoral and senior level scientists in the US and worldwide; it should be a significant contribution as a general resource in this area of science and technology.
